title: Applications of Random Algebraic Constructions to Hardness of Approximation
abstract:
Abstract.
In this paper, we show how one may (efficiently) construct two types of extremal combinatorial objects whose existence was previously conjectural.


‚Ä¢

Panchromatic Graphs: For fixed k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}, a kùëòk-panchromatic graph is, roughly speaking, a balanced bipartite graph with one partition class equipartitioned into kùëòk colour classes in which the common neighbourhoods of panchromatic kùëòk-sets of vertices are much larger than those of kùëòk-sets that repeat a colour. The question of their existence was raised by Karthik and Manurangsi¬†[Combinatorica¬†2020].



‚Ä¢

Threshold Graphs: For fixed k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}, a kùëòk-threshold graph is, roughly speaking, a balanced bipartite graph in which the common neighbourhoods of kùëòk-sets of vertices on one side are much larger than those of (k+1)ùëò1(k+1)-sets. The question of their existence was raised by Lin¬†[JACM¬†2018].



Concretely, we provide probability distributions over graphs from which we can efficiently sample these objects in near linear time. These probability distributions are defined via varieties cut out by (carefully chosen) random polynomials, and the analysis of these constructions relies on machinery from algebraic geometry (such as the Lang‚ÄìWeil estimate, for example). The technical tools developed to accomplish this might be of independent interest.
As applications of our constructions, we show the following conditional time lower bounds on the parameterized set intersection problem where, given a collection of nùëõn sets over universe [n]delimited-[]ùëõ[n] and a parameter kùëòk, the goal is to find kùëòk sets with the largest intersection.


‚Ä¢

Assuming ùñ§ùñ≥ùñßùñ§ùñ≥ùñß\mathsf{ETH}, for any computable function F:‚Ñï‚Üí‚Ñï:ùêπ‚Üí‚Ñï‚ÑïF\colon\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N}, no no‚Äã(k)superscriptùëõùëúùëòn^{o(k)}-time algorithm can approximate the parameterized set intersection problem up to factor F‚Äã(k)ùêπùëòF(k). This improves considerably on the previously best-known result under ùñ§ùñ≥ùñßùñ§ùñ≥ùñß\mathsf{ETH} due to Lin¬†[JACM¬†2018], who ruled out any no‚Äã(k)superscriptùëõùëúùëòn^{o(\sqrt{k})} time approximation algorithm for this problem.



‚Ä¢

Assuming ùñ≤ùñ§ùñ≥ùñßùñ≤ùñ§ùñ≥ùñß\mathsf{SETH}, for every Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 and any computable function F:‚Ñï‚Üí‚Ñï:ùêπ‚Üí‚Ñï‚ÑïF\colon\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N}, no nk‚àíŒµsuperscriptùëõùëòùúÄn^{k-\varepsilon}-time algorithm can approximate the parameterized set intersection problem up to factor F‚Äã(k)ùêπùëòF(k). No result of comparable strength was previously known under ùñ≤ùñ§ùñ≥ùñßùñ≤ùñ§ùñ≥ùñß\mathsf{SETH}, even for solving this problem exactly.



Both these time lower bounds are obtained by composing panchromatic graphs with instances of the coloured variant of the parameterized set intersection problem (for which tight lower bounds were previously known).
